{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3142132,"name":"Bryn Dole - programming mentor FRC 2930","username":"randomstring","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/randomstring/{size}/170695_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-08T22:29:57.334Z","cooked":"

Engineering is ready to cut some side plates, and I’m still trying to figure out what our optimal camera mounting location should be .

Looking around I’ve found hints (Limelight 3 April Tags spazzing out, need tuning help - #6 by Brandon_Hjelstrom) and (PhotonVision and tags heights) but nothing concrete.

My takeaways from what I’ve researched is that the camera should

  1. NOT be straight on, level, with the AprilTag
  2. NOT be angled level to the ground
  3. YES, be angled up or down about 10-15 degrees

I understand suggestion 1, as the orientation of the tags are less ambiguous if the target appears as a trapezoid. Viewing the tags at or close to straight on will make the tags look close to square.

Suggestion 2 & 3 I don’t quite understand. I’m struggling to see how the camera angle, independent of the camera height, contributes to less tag ambiguity. If the camera is mounted level with an AprilTag, the angle isn’t going to effect the shape of the tag. Except for lens distortion that is presumably being accounted for by the camera configuration.

This year’s AprilTags are mounted at 18.22 and 27.38 inches (0.462788 and 0.695452 meters respectively) [unless you’re looking at the field build docs which has them at 18.25 inches?] As noted in one of the CD threads, these heights are in the sweet spot for where one might naturally want to mount a camera to a robot.

My thinking is that 22.8" off the ground (the midpoint of both low and high tags) might be a good compromise. Although that is only about 4.5" of offset from the AprilTags. Is that enough? If you’re looking at a tag 15-20 feet away, that is not a significant height difference. Or mount them as high as possible on the robot, above 28" off the ground? That seems impractical as robots will mostly be all moving parts up high.

The other options is to mount the camera as low as possible and angled up. Higher mount points might subject the camera to more wobble if there’s play in the structure. Lower camera mounts angled up might be subject to more glare from bright lights. I don’t have access to the official anti-glare AprilTag covers so I’m not sure how worried I should be about glare. On our printed AprilTags, the black laserjet ink catches a lot of glare. Presumably auto-exposure should be turned off to avoid surprise changes to exposure that will effect the vision pipeline.

For reference, our team is planning to run two Arducam 120fps Global Shutter OV9281 USB cameras on a single OrangePi 5. Each has a 70deg FOV. The plan is to 3d print custom mounts and bolt them to the frame of our robot.

Not that I need to say this on CD, but I’m fishing for a few “that sounds right” or “WRONG, here’s why…”

I can only tell you what I’ve recommended to my team (and we’re implementing) based on responses in the second conversation you reference above. At first I was thinking that a minimum camera height would give maximum vertical difference from aprilTags, but 1) that’s not true when robot is on CS and given the limits of “minimum” above bumpers etc., and 2) a very low camera is more likely to have field tags obscured by CS itself and other robots. So our design is for camera at max pre-start height of 4’6” less 1”-2” for margin of error.

I quickly dismissed consideration of extension to post-start maximum. Besides all the extra engineering and “shakiness” that would entail, there is also too much uncertainty: 1) uncertainty of how much advantage that would gain, 2) uncertainty introduced of exact camera height, and especially 3) uncertainty introduced of exact camera tilt, which is crucial.
